title: A Multicenter, Uncontrolled, Open-label Trial to Evaluate the Safety of Extended Treatment With Brexpiprazole (OPC-34712) to Patients With Agitation Associated With Dementia of the Alzheimer's Type
description_brief: To evaluate the safety of brexpiprazole 1 mg or 2 mg after a 14 week treatment regimen for agitation associated with dementia of the Alzheimer's type patients who completed in a double-blind trial, and to investigate the efficacy of brexpiprazole.

outcomeMeasures.title: The Frequency of Subjects With Treatment-Emergent Adverse Events (TEAEs)
outcomeMeasures.description: This trial enrolled subjects rolled over from Trial 331-102-00088, and the safety of brexpiprazole when administered for a maximum of 24 weeks (including the treatment period of Trial 331-102-00088) was evaluated.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: The safety analysis set comprised subjects who have received at least 1 dose of the IMP.

outcomeMeasures.title: Mean Change From Baseline in Cohen-Mansfield Agitation Inventory (CMAI) Score at 14 Weeks After Dosing
outcomeMeasures.description: The CMAI assessed the frequency of agitated behaviors in elderly persons, such as hitting, cursing, and restlessness. It consisted of 29 items all rated on a 1 to 7 scale with 1 being the "best" rating and 7 being the "worst" rating. The minimum possible CMAI total score was 29, and the maximum possible CMAI total score was 203. A decrease in score indicated improvement in symptoms.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: The efficacy analysis set will comprise subjects who have received at least 1 dose of the IMP and from whom CMAI total scores have been obtained at baseline and at least 1 time point after initiation of treatment.

outcomeMeasures.title: Mean Change From Baseline in Clinical Global Impression of Severity (CGI-S) Score at 14 Weeks After Dosing.
outcomeMeasures.description: The CGI-S was used to rate the severity of agitation. Scores were: 0 = not assessed; 1 = normal, not at all ill; 2 = borderline mentally ill; 3 = mildly ill; 4 = moderately ill; 5 = markedly ill; 6 = severely ill; and 7 = among the most extremely ill participants. A decrease in score indicated improvement in symptoms.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: The efficacy analysis set will comprise subjects who have received at least 1 dose of the IMP and from whom CMAI total scores have been obtained at baseline and at least 1 time point after initiation of treatment.

outcomeMeasures.title: Clinical Global Impression of Improvement (CGI-I) Score at 14 Weeks After Dosing
outcomeMeasures.description: The CGI-I Scale was clinician-rated scale which assessed the total improvement of the patient's condition compared to that at baseline. Scores range from 0 to 7: 0 = Not assessed, 1= Very much improved, 2 = Much improved, 3= Minimally improved, 4= No change, 5= Minimally worse, 6= Much worse, 7= Very much worse. Higher scores indicate worse condition.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: The efficacy analysis set will comprise subjects who have received at least 1 dose of the IMP and from whom CMAI total scores have been obtained at baseline and at least 1 time point after initiation of treatment.

adverseEventsModule.timeFrame: Adverse events were monitored from signing of the informed consent form through 35 days after last dose of study drug (Up to approximately Week 19)
adverseEventsModule.description: Subjects who received at least one dose of IMP were included in the safety analysis.

drug: Brexpiprazole (OPC-34712; brand name REXULTI) — a small‑molecule atypical antipsychotic / serotonin–dopamine activity modulator (partial agonist at D2 and 5‑HT1A; antagonist at 5‑HT2A).
placebo: Placebo (used as comparator in the double‑blind randomized brexpiprazole trials referenced in the description).
explanation_target: Reason: The trial title and description explicitly state the population and intent: "agitation associated with dementia of the Alzheimer's type" and evaluation of brexpiprazole safety/efficacy in that indication. citeturn0search0

Act: The investigational drug is brexpiprazole (OPC‑34712), marketed as REXULTI; it is a small‑molecule atypical antipsychotic (serotonin‑dopamine activity modulator). citeturn1search7turn1search3

Act (evidence of efficacy/safety focus): Randomized controlled trials and publications report brexpiprazole reduces agitation in Alzheimer dementia vs placebo and the program includes double‑blind placebo‑controlled studies; the described study is an open‑label extension evaluating longer‑term safety after those trials. citeturn0search7turn0search1

Reflect: This intervention targets a neuropsychiatric symptom (agitation) through neurotransmitter modulation rather than targeting Alzheimer pathophysiology (amyloid/tau) or directly enhancing cognition. Therefore it fits the 'neuropsychiatric symptom improvement' category, not the disease‑targeted or cognitive‑enhancer categories. citeturn1search3turn0search2

Additional supporting facts / citations: REXULTI (brexpiprazole) is indicated for treatment of agitation associated with dementia due to Alzheimer's disease (regulatory approval/labeling and sponsor publications describe this indication). citeturn1search6turn1search8
explanation_agent: Reason: The trial tests brexpiprazole (REXULTI) for agitation in Alzheimer's disease; brexpiprazole is an atypical antipsychotic/serotonin–dopamine activity modulator (partial agonist at dopamine D2 and serotonin 5‑HT1A; antagonist at serotonin 5‑HT2A). This indicates the intervention acts by modulating neurotransmitter receptors to reduce neuropsychiatric symptoms rather than targeting core AD pathologies (amyloid, tau) or metabolic/vascular pathways. citeturn0search1turn0search3

Act: Extracted details — drug: brexpiprazole (OPC‑34712; REXULTI). Mechanism: partial agonist at D2 and 5‑HT1A and antagonist at 5‑HT2A (neurotransmitter receptor modulation). Indication/context: treatment of agitation associated with dementia due to Alzheimer’s disease (studies and FDA approval for this indication). These facts are supported by the FDA approval announcement and prescribing information. citeturn0search0turn0search3

Reflect: Classification check — CADRO category D) Neurotransmitter Receptors best fits because the mechanism is direct neurotransmitter receptor modulation (dopamine and serotonin receptors) and the trial aims to treat a neuropsychiatric symptom (agitation). This is not a disease‑modifying approach targeting amyloid, tau, inflammation, proteostasis, vasculature, or other CADRO categories, nor is it a diagnostic/non‑therapeutic study. Therefore D) is the appropriate single category (not R) Multi‑target). citeturn0search0turn0search5
